import "./ahc.css" export default function Ahc9() { return (

The role of your family and friends in shaping your habits

  • The lone wolf dies but the pack survives
  • Humans are social creatures - we want to fit in, bond with others, earn the respect and approval of our peers
  • We donâ€™t choose our earliest habits it is handed to us by the society we live in
  • We imitate habits of 3 groups in particular
  • The close (family and friends)
  • Our friends and family provides us a sort of invisible peer pressure that pulls us in their direction
  • One of the best way to build habits is to join culture where the desired behavior is the normal behavior
  • If you are surrounded by fit people you are likely to consider working out to be a common habit
  • Your culture sets your expectations of whats normal
  • The many (the tribe)
  • The normal behaviour of the tribe often overpowers the desired behaviour of the individual
  • There is tremendous internal pressure to comply with the norms of the group
  • The reward of getting accepted is often greater than the reward of winning an argument, looking smart or finding the truth.
  • Most days we rather be wrong with the crowd than be right ourselves
  • When changing your habits means challenging the tribe, change is unattractive, when changing your habits means fitting in with the tribe change is very attractive
  • The powerful (those with status and prestige)
  • Historically a person with greater power and status has access to more resources, worries less about survival and proves to be a more successful mate
  • Many of our daily habits are imitations of the people we desire. We try to copy the behaviour of successful people because we desire success ourselves
  • Once we fit in we start looking for ways to stand out
) }
